text: Right. I'll read mainly the  the changes that will be enforced while we are doing virtual meetings. As authorized by ordinance of the county of Albemarle, the school board will hold its meetings electronically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The school board is nevertheless committed to encouraging public comment despite its need to meet on a virtual basis. And because of that change, we'll have two main changes or two main ways of having people communicate with us.  First, written comments may be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting and will be disseminated to all of the school board members for review. Secondly, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the school board meeting may sign up online at our website by 4pm the day before the meeting. The clerk will email Zoom links to the speakers on the day of the meeting so that they can log into the meeting to provide comment.  Before electronic public comment commences, the vice chair will announce the order in which the speakers will comment. Public commenters will initially be admitted to a waiting room on Zoom until it is their turn to speak. They will be able to hear the meeting in progress while they wait. Each speaker's access to the public comment will be activated when it is that speaker's turn to provide comment to the members of the school board.  Speakers will be notified when they reach the two-minute mark, and at the three-minute mark, the speaker's Zoom link will be automatically deactivated. Although the school board is confident that public comment will proceed in an orderly and respectful manner, upon instructions from the chair, the clerk may deactivate the speaker's mic at any time.  Speakers during the meeting or those submitting written comment should state name and address or magisterial district. Simply stating Albemarle County for your address is not adequate. Although the school board will not respond to comments made during the public comment period, school board members may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business. So those are the primary changes that we'll be having while we are having a virtual meeting.

text: Yes, thank you. So we have a resolution. I'm going to read it now. It's in regard to the Child Nutrition Services. Whereas on Friday, March 13,  Virginia Governor Ralph Northam ordered the closing of all schools in the Commonwealth for a period of two weeks to protect against the spread of the coronavirus. And whereas this action to protect public health through the closure of schools meant that students who participated in the federal government's free and reduced lunch program lost their access to the nutritious meals provided each day at school and  Whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools, thousands of students were negatively impacted by this loss of access. And whereas among the school division's four values is its young people, specifically their academic and personal development, their health and well-being,  And whereas in response to the closure of schools, the division's child nutrition department immediately began to plan to meet the needs of all children for healthy breakfast and lunches on a daily basis.  And whereas within one business day of the governor's closure announcement, Child Nutrition Team members, under the guidance of Director Christina Pitzenberger, had organized a food distribution program. And whereas the program began with six school sites throughout the county, serving more than 1,000 meals a day to students and their siblings 18 years of old and younger. And whereas on March 23rd,  The governor extended the closure of all K-12 schools in the Commonwealth through the end of the current academic year, and whereas the Child Nutrition Office continued to monitor the need among its students and all communities across the county for healthy meals and to work with the Department of Transportation in setting up additional food distribution sites,  And whereas, as the result of this ongoing planning and teamwork, the office now distributes breakfast and lunches to students in 21 locations at schools and communities. And whereas, since March 17th, the Child Nutrition Office has provided more than 30,000 meals to students from all schools and locations in the county, and is continuing to evaluate the needs to further expand this service.  Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board expresses its deep appreciation to Ms. Pitsenberger and her highly dedicated and skilled team for their invaluable support in meeting the nutritional and health needs of thousands of Albemarle County public school students and their siblings, and for doing so through such an expeditious and increasingly inclusive plan.  And be it further resolved, the school board also salutes the contributions of the transportation department, its director James Foley, and his team for enabling the food distribution program to bring its services directly to the neighborhoods where students reside, thereby expanding participation in this vitally beneficial program. Thank you.

text: Hi, everyone. Well, this is a new one for all of us, so bear with me here. But first of all, thank you for letting me join in.  And I want to let you know how very, very much we do appreciate our special educators. We appreciate all they do on a regular basis, but even right now, they are making a difference every day as we all try to adjust to the new normal. This report was written before the virus changed our education model, so it may not feel as relevant right now, but the recommendations are going to be key when we get back into the classroom, which hopefully will be sooner rather than later, and will help us with the continuing improvement of the ACPS special education model.  Our first point was that we would really like to see Albemarle County implement the Safe Schools Ambassador Program. It's already in use in 41 states and over 2,000 schools to reduce bullying in the school systems. It's research-based. It's been field-tested. The process is they recruit students in grades four through 12. They look for the social leaders, the social influencers, and they train them in how to defuse, safely defuse a bullying situation.  We know that students are present in the majority of bullying incidents, and this is their chance to step up and help often before teachers or administrators can even get to the scene. The study showed that the State Schools Ambassador Program decreases bullying and all the costs of the associated related suspensions. It increases attendance, it increases academic performance, it increases the respect for diversity, which goes on to our second point, diversity.  The special education advisory committee members are requesting that special education be considered in the culturally responsive teaching initiative. Our students, many of them have a culture of their own. If you Google autism culture, you'll get multiple results on autism awareness and neurodiversity organizations. The deaf and hard of hearing have had a culture of their own recognized for decades. And even ADHD has a culture of its own.  If you doubt that one, try attending their international conference and watch the attendees just come alive when they're surrounded by people who really understand them and who know what's going on in their world. They talk about overcoming challenges and they talk about adapting to their situations, but they also really celebrate their gifts. And folks with ADHD have a lot of gifts that often get missed in the typical classroom setting.  Our third priority is to include the SPED community in the contemporary schooling initiative. We had a wonderful presentation on what's coming up with contemporary schooling, but it worried us a bit to know that Murray and the Community Public Charter School are moving away from the mastery learning and into a new IB program. Our students with some challenges are losing a valuable opportunity for learning there. That mastery model worked particularly well for a number of our students with some disabilities.  If the SPED is included in the planning, we can make sure that all our students have a place in this new venture. It's exciting. We want to be involved. Our fourth priority is additional training for teachers and staff on ADHD and on the executive function challenges that come with it.  We hear this from parents, from students, from teachers, from administrators, that our schools really need more training in this. It affects all students with or without disabilities. That part of the brain that regulates executive function doesn't fully come online until about age 25 and sometimes later. So all of our students would benefit. Also, our students would benefit as the teachers gain a little better control of the classroom. If you're not having to stop  and work with those students who ADHD behaviors are disrupting learning, you get more time for teaching. And we're talking about approximately 11 percent of the students in our school system having ADHD. So every classroom is affected. Our final priority is ensuring that families get the information they need to work with the schools to help our students. Albemarle County Public Schools is leaving the Parent Resource Center, and a lot of us have counted on that resource.  We want to be sure that we get a parent-centered, student-focused, and most importantly, impartial source of information. I have two special education students of my own, and the process was initially terrifying and a bit contentious even. Once I knew how the process worked, I understood the acronyms, I was able to develop the relationship with the teachers and the administration, the entire process changed.  And I know for other parents, this process can go from frightening to uplifting when they know what's going on and how to work with the schools instead of feeling like we're working against them. As SEAC members, we hear this from a lot of parents frequently. The process is scary if you're not used to it and the acronyms are confusing.  That's the end of the presentation part. I do really want to say thank you so much to Kevin Kirst and Katie Kompel and the entire special education team for their exceptional support of our students and especially during this incredibly challenging time. Thank you to the school board for letting me present this evening.
